author: Dan O'Donoghue
title: North East could lose up to £430m in European aid after Brexit
text:
North East could lose up to £430m in European aid after Brexit 06:30, 6 Jul 2016 The EU money helps cut poverty in deprived areas and is also spent on regional infrastructure to boost growth Shares Get daily news by email A member of protocol adjusts the British flag at EU headquarters in Brussels 
The North East stands to lose more than £400million in European aid following the Brexit vote. 
The Leave campaign promised to honour existing European Union grants, including funds for regional development, until 2020. 
But experts fear the much-needed cash could disappear unless the government has “comprehensive plans” in place to boost regional economies after Brexit . 
Across the country it is estimated that around £8.6billion in European grants could be pulled. 
Aside from European aid more than £1.5bn has been wiped off the value of listed North East firms since the vote. 
The Joseph Rowntree Foundation says it is vital the UK holds on to the allocated cash and it is not “clawed back”. Regions that benefited most from EU funding, like the North East, were among those that resoundingly voted for Brexit. 
In all, 1.34 million of us turned out to vote on June 23 - with 778,103 siding with leave and 562,595 with remain, meaning a resounding 58% voted for Brexit. 
Helen Barnard, of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, said: “The referendum has exposed the extent to which people in the poorest places feel shut out from the benefits of the country’s prosperity. 
“These figures show the challenge in ensuring they do not fall further behind from lost EU funding after 2020.” 
She said, without action, initiatives such as the Northern Powerhouse “risk withering after Brexit”. 
Council leaders are seeking urgent assurances from the Government that town halls will still get the £5.3billion in EU regeneration funding allocated up to 2020. 
The Local Government Association is assessing the impact Brexit will have on local communities at its annual conference in Bournemouth. 
Lord Porter, LGA chairman, said: “Communities also need assurances from the Government that they will still receive billions of pounds worth of EU funding to create jobs and boost growth.”
